Balearica regulorum gibbericeps, commonly known as the South African crowned crane, is a subspecies of the grey crowned crane found in parts of Southern Africa. It is a large, graceful bird that belongs to the family Gruidae, which includes cranes.

The South African crowned crane is characterized by its distinctive black and white plumage, with a prominent crown of stiff, golden-colored feathers on its head. Its face is mostly white, with a black stripe running from the eye to the back of the head. The bird's body is predominantly grey, with black primary and secondary flight feathers.

One of the unique features of this subspecies is the presence of a prominent, bony protuberance on the top of its head, known as a "gibbericeps," which is larger in males than in females. This feature is believed to play a role in sexual display and communication within the species.

Balearica regulorum gibbericeps is found in a range of habitats, including savannas, grasslands, and wetlands, where it feeds on a variety of plant matter, insects, and small vertebrates. The species is known for its elaborate courtship displays, which include dancing, wing-flapping, and vocalizations.

Conservation-wise, the South African crowned crane is classified as Vulnerable by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), primarily due to habitat loss and degradation, as well as hunting and capture for the pet trade.
